channel.title: [EasyRSC] [Error] Cannot assign requested address: bind
channel.description:
Hi there, Shel here. Here's the basics of my issue: I compile my server to make sure no java is running. I run the .bat file to launch my server. My server launches. I press Start Server. Here's where the problem arises: I get this error message [code][Error] Cannot assign requested address: bind [Error] [Ljava.lang.StackTraceElement;@******[/code] (the * is a wildcard ~any number or letter, seems to be from A-F 0-9) Been doing a bit of searching into this problem, can't find ANYTHING that can help me with it.
Here's what I've done to the server so far in an attempt to make it public: Changed "localhost" in Server.java to "192.168.0.1"(my router's IP) Changed Conf.xml around a bit. Changed the settings.ini in the Client config; the client is not at fault, it can connect using localhost if I change the string in Server.java back to localhost. Changed settings in my router to allow Port Forwarding to my computer(ports 27000-27030, 43594, 34522) Changed the server settings to use 27015 instead of 43594 for the port number.
Any ideas?
MSN : d.487@hotmail.com

item.title: [EasyRSC] [Error] Cannot assign requested address: bind
item.dc:creator: @xShel xShel
item.description:
@xShel wrote:

Ah, I only did to test all the ports instead of screwing with port forwarding every 15 seconds.

Going to try it in Ubuntu now, see if that works. If not I’ll just get Steam working for future use

Okay, this is a bit different, now I just get [Error] Cannot assign requested address.

Apparently searching into this it’s a problem with Vista, so maybe it’s a problem with windows 7 too? there’s gotta be a fix.

Read full topic

item.title: [EasyRSC] [Error] Cannot assign requested address: bind
item.dc:creator: @adu adu
item.description:
@adu wrote:

[quote=“xShel, post:9, topic:353869”]I was told it was to be the default gateway and not my computers IP, but i’ll try that.
also put my computer in DMZ mode.[/quote]

FYI, never put your computers ip on DMZ.

Read full topic

item.title: [EasyRSC] [Error] Cannot assign requested address: bind
item.dc:creator: @xShel xShel
item.description:
@xShel wrote:

I was told it was to be the default gateway and not my computers IP, but i’ll try that.
also put my computer in DMZ mode.

EDIT:
Nope, 192.168.0.12(my computers IP) does not work at all… it doesn’t have the bind error, but I can’t connect to it.

Read full topic

item.title: [EasyRSC] [Error] Cannot assign requested address: bind
item.dc:creator: @adu adu
item.description:
@adu wrote:

Your ip in the server class is wrong. It needs to be your individual computers internal ip address like “192.168.0.12” not the routers ip address.

Read full topic

item.title: [EasyRSC] [Error] Cannot assign requested address: bind
item.dc:creator: @xShel xShel
item.description:
@xShel wrote:

My firewalls disabled
Vanilla install of EasyRSC v1.1 doesn’t work.
Using Windows 7 as my base OS if that counts towards anything. I could change it to ubuntu and try.

Read full topic

item.title: [EasyRSC] [Error] Cannot assign requested address: bind

item.description:
@uberpk3r wrote:

You will also need to port-forward in your firewall.

item.title: [EasyRSC] [Error] Cannot assign requested address: bind
item.dc:creator: @xShel xShel
item.description:
@xShel wrote:

Hi there, Shel here.
Here’s the basics of my issue:
I compile my server to make sure no java is running.
I run the .bat file to launch my server.
My server launches.
I press Start Server.
Here’s where the problem arises: I get this error message

[Error] Cannot assign requested address: bind [Error] [Ljava.lang.StackTraceElement;@******
(the * is a wildcard ~any number or letter, seems to be from A-F 0-9)
Been doing a bit of searching into this problem, can’t find ANYTHING that can help me with it.

Here’s what I’ve done to the server so far in an attempt to make it public:
Changed “localhost” in Server.java to “192.168.0.1”(my router’s IP)
Changed Conf.xml around a bit.
Changed the settings.ini in the Client config; the client is not at fault, it can connect using localhost if I change the string in Server.java back to localhost.
Changed settings in my router to allow Port Forwarding to my computer(ports 27000-27030, 43594, 34522)
Changed the server settings to use 27015 instead of 43594 for the port number.

Any ideas?

MSN : d.487@hotmail.com

Read full topic
